verses.text: The divisions of the gatekeepers: Of the Korahites, Meshelemiah son of Kore, from the sons of Asaph.
verses.comment: Maintains direct list structure as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: Meshelemiah had sons: Zechariah the firstborn, Jediael the second, Zebadiah the third, Jathniel the fourth,
verses.comment: Preserves birth order and names; follows Hebrew lineage listing.

verses.text: Elam the fifth, Jehohanan the sixth, Eliehoenai the seventh.
verses.comment: Standardized spelling for clarity, maintains original sequence.

verses.text: Obed-Edom also had sons: Shemaiah the firstborn, Jehozabad the second, Joah the third, Sacar the fourth, Nethanel the fifth,
verses.comment: No textual differences; names as in Masoretic Text.

verses.text: Ammiel the sixth, Issachar the seventh, Peullthai the eighth; for God had blessed him.
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine blessing per contextual cross-reference.

verses.text: His son Shemaiah also had sons, who were leaders in their father's family, strong men of ability.
verses.comment: Translates Hebrew ‘mighty men of strength’ into modern ‘strong men of ability’ for clarity.

verses.text: The sons of Shemaiah were Othni, Rephael, Obed, Elzabad, whose relatives Elihu and Semachiah were also able men.
verses.comment: Includes the family relations per the original intent.

verses.text: All these were descendants of Obed-Edom. They and their sons and relatives were able men, qualified for their service—sixty-two from Obed-Edom.
verses.comment: Clarifies ‘qualified for their service’; original meaning retained.

verses.text: Meshelemiah had sons and relatives, eighteen able men.
verses.comment: No significant textual notes; preserves numeric data.

verses.text: Hosa, one of the Merarites, had sons: Shimri was the chief, though he was not the firstborn, his father made him chief.
verses.comment: Retains unusual detail about succession, true to original wording.

verses.text: Hilkiah the second, Tebaliah the third, Zechariah the fourth. All the sons and relatives of Hosa were thirteen.
verses.comment: Numeric accuracy maintained, names spelled phonetically.

verses.text: These divisions of the gatekeepers were assigned duties, like their relatives, to serve in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Notes familial assignment and Levitical structure; faithful rendering.

verses.text: They cast lots, large and small alike, for their gate assignments, each gatekeeper according to his family.
verses.comment: ‘Cast lots’ is an ancient practice, translated into modern phrasing for clarity.

verses.text: The lot for the east gate fell to Shelemiah. Then they cast lots for Zechariah his son, a wise counselor, and the north gate fell to him.
verses.comment: ‘Wise counselor’ reflects Hebrew ‘counsel of understanding’.

verses.text: Obed-Edom’s lot fell for the south gate, and his sons were assigned the storehouse.
verses.comment: Clarifies physical layout of assignments per original text.

verses.text: Shuppim and Hosa were assigned the west gate and the gate by the road up to the temple, with guardians on alternating duty.
verses.comment: ‘Guardians on alternating duty’ expresses the Hebrew ‘guard with guard’.

verses.text: On the east six Levites were assigned each day, on the north four each day, on the south four each day, and at the storehouse two by two.
verses.comment: Numerical distribution kept literal as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: At the court to the west, four were at the road, and two at the court itself.
verses.comment: ‘Court itself’ clarifies Hebrew for modern readers; meaning unchanged.

verses.text: These are the divisions of the gatekeepers among the families of the Korahites and the Merarites.
verses.comment: Concludes the gatekeeper list as in the original.

verses.text: Other Levites: Ahijah entrusted the treasures of God’s house and the dedicated gifts.
verses.comment: ‘Entrusted’ reflects Hebrew ‘guarded over’; no theological difference.

verses.text: The sons of Ladan, from Gershonites through Ladan: chiefs of Ladan’s families were Jehieli.
verses.comment: Maintains genealogical clarity.

verses.text: The sons of Jehieli: Zetham and his brother Joel managed the treasures of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Managed’ translates Hebrew ‘were over’; original content preserved.

verses.text: From the Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites, and Uzzielites:
verses.comment: List preserved as in original Hebrew.

verses.text: Shebuel son of Gershom, son of Moses, was chief over the treasures.
verses.comment: Genealogical note clarifies Shebuel’s lineage per cross-reference.

verses.text: His relatives through Eliezer: Rehabiah his son, Jeshaiah his son, Joram his son, Zichri his son, and Shelomith his son.
verses.comment: Maintains the original genealogical ordering.

verses.text: Shelomith and his relatives were responsible for all the treasures of the dedicated gifts by King David, the heads of families, commanders of thousands and hundreds, and other army leaders.
verses.comment: ‘Responsible for all the treasures’ clarifies the phrase for modern readers.

verses.text: They dedicated some of the spoils of war to maintain the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Spoils of war’ is a direct translation of Hebrew; ‘maintenance’ clarifies intended use.

verses.text: Everything Samuel the seer, Saul son of Kish, Abner son of Ner, and Joab son of Zeruiah had dedicated—everything anyone dedicated—was under the care of Shelomith and his relatives.
verses.comment: Summarizes list of donors as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: From the Izharites: Chenaniah and his sons were assigned outside duties for Israel as officers and judges.
verses.comment: ‘Outside duties’ means civil rather than temple service; accurate rendering.

verses.text: From the Hebronites: Hashabiah and his relatives, seventeen hundred able men, managed Israel’s affairs west of the Jordan for all the work of the LORD and service to the king.
verses.comment: Details preserved as in original; ‘managed Israel’s affairs’ clarifies duty.

verses.text: Of the Hebronites: Jeriah was chief of the Hebronites according to the genealogies of their families. In the fortieth year of David’s reign, a search was made, and there were found among them capable men at Jazer in Gilead.
verses.comment: Mentions David’s fortieth year as in Masoretic Text; emphasis on historical detail.

verses.text: Jeriah’s relatives—two thousand seven hundred able men, heads of families—were appointed by King David over the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh for every matter relating to God and to the king’s service.
verses.comment: Numbers kept literal; ‘every matter relating to God and king’s service’ gives the sense of complete oversight.
